description: The Filipino food that they serve at Inay is pretty legit. I thought the lady at the cashier wasn't very welcoming when I talked to her in Filipino. But I was too hungry to mind.  I ordered adobo and pansit ($12.49). For dessert, I got myself some halo-halo ($5.69). Will come back for sure!
author: Paolo B.

description:
I was here a couple of times for my lunch. This place is inside Metreon, so you can buy your food and there are several shared tables where you can eat. 
I was not impressed with the food. Two times it was only slightly warm, probably heated in a microwave and a meat was over-fried(too dry and tasteless, I couldn't taste anything but sauce). 
Never experienced rude service or something like other reviewers mentioned, but food wise it's not my place.
author: Dmytro Z.

description:
It was our first time here and I was just asking some questions but the guy who was grilling woke up at the wrong side of the bed and responded "only the turo turo! Same routine as always." Well, I do not know the routine being an out of towner. 

It was a total turn off at least the lady at the cashier was a nice grandma.

The food was not that spectacular -- coupled with his rudeness. No thank you.
author: Al N.

description:
First of all the one of the helper from the counter is rude we just got there to  look at the menu we're trying to decide which ones we wanted to order.
First she asked us can I help you we're still deciding what to eat and it wasn't busy at all. She was standing there waiting for us and we're still not ready to eat and she walk away and said just let me know when you're ready in a rude way. 
So we're ready to order she didn't come another helper from the counter helped us in a nice way. She being friendly. 
Now we talk about the food it's nasty. The barbecue pork was too hard to eat. The pancit was dry and the lumpia was ok. 
I won't recommend this place to my friends. 
That's why they deserve one star.
author: Lorie Anne B.

description:
This was my first Filipino food experience. I ordered the Sisig Fries, the Good Boy fried rice, and the Menudo. I was pleasantly surprised when my food arrived, with the time they took to package everything neatly. They took extra precautions to make sure nothing was spilling out the sides. 
All of my dishes looked exactly like the pictures they have online so kudos! I loved everything I ordered the flavor was amazing. The fries were a little spicy loved that. I definitely had a happy belly! Their portions were satisfying, and the food was delicious. I will definitely be back.
author: Ashley R.

description:
I always feel happy when I see small Filipino Restaurants do so well, and I think Inay's does so well in the Metreon! I came here on a Saturday and ordered a one item plate with steam rice and Pork Sinigang. I also got extra sabaw (broth) for .25. 

It came a little over $11 which is a little pricey for me, but this IS San Francisco and I was a fan of their Sinigang so it was worth it. They had all the good veggies in the Sinigang like bokchoy, daikon, onion, tomato, green beans, and eggplant! The only bummer was that the meat to rice ratio didn't match. 

My boyfriend also ordered a plate; he got garlic rice (with extra garlic), sweet longanisa (sp), and lumpia. Their garlic rice was pretty awesome! Their dishes are cooked very well and the way I liked it, so this place gets 4 stars. 

They also had some fusion foods such as lechon fries and nachos!
author: Meliza M.

description:
A coworker of mine is a light eater. When she offered to share her lunch, my inner fatty took her up on the offer. She grabbed her meal on Monday, November 13th around 2:15pm from Inay Filipino Kitchen.

She's not very adventurous, so she just got the Lumpia Shanghai: Pork eggrolls with Sweet-n-Sour sauce, Chili Vinegar, or Sweet Chili sauce. These were crispy, but I actually found them a little bland tasting. I love a nice meaty lumpia and these were missing that savory porky flavor. Kind of a bummer as I adore fried foods. Especially anything egg roll like. Otherwise, they did the trick and satisfied that salty snack craving.

Decent place to grab a quick meal if you're at the Metreon and craving Filipino food.
author: Elena N.

description: Went here for lunch, super friendly staff, very helpful and informative instructing me on whats good and what to order. Unfortunately felt the food taste to be pretty underwhelming from other filipino food I have had in the past. I ordered a 1 item plate Chicken Adobo, half noodles half garlic rice, and everything was just ok. Nothing impressively stood out besides it being a decent portion size.
author: LeVar H.

description:
This place was just so-so. I had it as part of a Meal Pal option which came with the Pork Adobo and Garlic Rice. All of it just tasted relatively mediocre though, especially compared to the Filipino food down in SoCal which tastes a lot better than what I had here.

The pork was relatively dry in many parts, the rice and noodles tasted rather uninspired, it tasted like a bad attempt to copy Panda Express's noodles and fried rice. Overall quite a pass, and I don't think I'd come back here.
author: Tyler T.

description: This is one of my faves. The "good boy" fried rice is amazing and the entree selection is mouth watering. There's so much more to write but I would rather dream about the food than write about it.
author: Sunder I.

description: Thank you for the patience because I could not make up my mind. Workers were friendly when taking my order me. I recommend this place.
author: John Ezra S.

description: Just tried this today - awesome service and delicious food. It's been a while since I had Filipino food and this place was just the right place for it. Was here during the busy lunch hour and in spite of the long line, the service was remarkably efficient. Highly recommended if you are in the neighborhood!
author: Joon S.

description:
Order what is FRESH (off the grill), not necessarily what you may WANT or sounds good. It's true that the food can lack in flavor, texture, and freshness. Unfortunately, because I do enjoy Pinoy cuisine.

Staff was relatively friendly, but I had to ask for sauce (and you gonna need that sauce). Then there was a resentment as I left when I sampled a bite of the MANY samples they were passing out. The fresh chicken morsel was the opposite of my own food: moist, fresh, and HOT off the grill. I had an over-cooked (small piece) of fish that costs extra, raw kale that chokes you, lukewarm pork menudo (that wasn't really menudo), and nothing I'd call pancit - tho' I wuz grateful for bits of food mixed into the tasteless noodle combination. 

The guy cooking that chicken did not SMILE once either, felt like he was glaring at customers sitting on stools eatin' their meals. Lol. I may try them again, but for a $15 lunch...I ain't in a rush.
author: Ziggy J.

description:
Came here right before closing and I couldn't order the pork sisig since they were cleaning their oven. Decided to go with Chicken Adobo. It was so soft and moist! Garlic rice was bomb. AND a really nice worker gave me an extra drumstick since they were closing up.

Why not 5 stars? Location :( I dont go to SOMA area often so I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. However, if I'm close by, would definitely come back again before closing to try some pork sisig OR sisig fries.
author: Cynthia M.

description: This location of Inay is inside of the Metreon food court, on the side closest to Target. They have tons of delicious classic Filipino dishes here and we were able to try most of them. The sisig was a bit dry once you finish eating the egg on top, but I enjoyed all of the thick cut onions with it. The lumpia was crunchy and not greasy at all. My two favorite dishes were the Bicol Express and Lechon Nachos. The Bicol Express was the perfect level of spicy. I just wanted to put the spicy coconut cream sauce on all of my food! The Lechon Nachos were unique and I've never seen anything like it before. Instead of tortilla chips, they use homemade banana chips, topped with lechon, crispy kale, sriracha cream sauce, and mango salsa. I need this dish to be served at a restaurant closer to home!
author: Ashley C.

description: One staff rude as hell. Never coming back. Was gonna get more stuff, not anymore. The one star was for the other staff who was nice and willing to answer my question - I only had one question. There was no one else in line. Took over 20 min for my food when they told me it would be 10 min. The menu said it would be 8-10 min. This is like a Panda Express fast food place, why would it take over 20 min? They put out part of my food while they prepared for the other half. By the time I got my food the part that was left out was cold and the lumpias are soggy. Lumpia is not supposed to be soggy ! She didn't give me any utensils despite being a take out. I went to grab some myself and found the utensils to be dirty, so gross ! Food was so salty to the point of bitter. Meat was too tough and dry. I had five bites and just couldn't take the excessive salt. Threw it out. Will never come back.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
This used to be my go to flipino spot, not after i got food poisoning today. I had lumpia and some pork meat. The lady that was helping me she was like literally breathing on my food. That is so not sanity like i ani't trynna have your germs on my food. And it is pretty over priced for two items $13.54. For the portions you get its not worth it, just head to westfield better food and better options. 
Perhaps the health inspectors can check this spot out and their cleanliness. They touch the food and the money and not wearing gloves. Disgusting.
author: Curry S.

description:
The 5-stars is solely because they have my all time favorite dish. DINIGUAN! I love them so much for having this item. Although it is an extra cost for this delicious item, it is fully worth in every way for me. Other than my favorite item, they always have such flavorful garlic rice, which I've learned is a staple to the Filipino community and their restaurants. It is always fully stocked during their lunch hours (which in my opinion should be the time you go and eat at any of the spots in this building) just because they are not all fully known for their dinner hours. Their chicken adobo is on point, delivering a promising flavor boat of traditional and unique flavors. Although I love it really tangy from the vinegar, they make theirs very neutral and provide extra vinegar cups for people like me, and no extra cost. 
Also, you can expect a very nice and welcoming staff. They are all willing to tend to their customer's needs and are always naturally positive about doing so. 
Keep up the great services and foods you provide!!! Thank you!
author: Nick A.

description: Thoroughly disappointing. I had their dinuguan the other day and discovered that it mostly contained pork fats! There was hardly any meats in it. So deceptive of them. What were they thinking? That people wouldn't notice that? We will never patronize Inay's again.
author: Susan Z.

description: It's a shame. I come here often as I live close by. I like their pinakbet.  Today I also ordered the pork skewer. I should have known by looking at it that it was in the warming tray for a long time. When I bit into it it was leather and I attempted to notify the staff and return it. What I was looking for was an exchange for a small portion of another pork dish.  This was not possible even though they acknowledged that the pork skewers were not good as they removed the other remaining skewer from the warming tray.  So instead they charged me for a full order of another pork dish.  Lost customer for life.
author: OneOfTwo F.

description: This is an authentic filipino restaurant. I was pleasantly surprised that their mongos has the same taste as my aunts in the philippines. This place is unpretentious, kind and authentic. I'm definitely coming back here again
author: Jouella F.

description:
I love this place. Authentic Filipino food cooked by authentic Filipinos. The people are friendly , the food is tasty, I admit there are some dishes which I would call an acquired taste. Each time my wife and I have gone the food has been very enjoyable. I usually get the Lechon and Sinegang ..but Ive had other dishes such as Menduo and their BBQ which are tasty. I love the garlic fried rice, but it doesnt like me as it gives me indigestion but nothing some green tea or a chew-able Alka Seltzer cant take of ! :) 
Its really nice to have a place that serves Filipino food downtown as oppose to going near or to Daly City..

And make sure you try the Halo Halo !! Yummy Yummy !
author: David S.

description: Lechon nacos were great! Also loved the pork belly.   I like this place alot and want to come back.
author: Michael E.

description: 1 star for the bbq chicken stick but the chicken adobo totally didn't taste like adobo  I dis not taste the vinegar or soy sauce. The garlic rice was very hard like it was old and the pancit was just ok. I don't think I will order from here again, I've had way better filipino food elsewhere.
author: Lennie G.

description:
Inay is nice for a quick lunch if you work in SoMa. The lines are a lot shorter than other places in the metreon. Their pork sisig was really yummy but the fried chicken we got was a bit undercooked. 

There are plenty of seats in the metreon as long as you don't go between 12-1pm.
author: Julia C.

description: Really good Filipino food, I wasn't expecting  the flavors to be that authentic since it was "mall" food, but everything was delicious! Sisig French fried, pork adobo, lechon and pancit were all delicious. And of course the halo halo was a nice bonus! Slightly pricey but your at the Metreon so to be expected. I would come back!
author: Three D.

description: This is a solid spot for a quick bite that will fill you up for $10-14. It's on the fatty side but boy do they blend the ingredients and flavors well!!! The Lechón tasted great with a good balance of tough and tender meat. The fries with mango sauce hit the SPOT and the fried kale was to die for. Do not come here if you're on a diet. Do come here if you're hungry and wanna experience a flavor explosion :p
author: Eileen T.

description: Their Lechon is SUPER GOOD! They use a garlic marinade a little different than the traditional soy sauce marinade, and it's really bomb. I wasn't sure what to expect since the metreon food court doesn't exactly seem like the spot to get good fillipino cusine, but I'm glad I gave them a shot because this has got to be one of the best hidden gem lunch spots in Fidi/soma. Also the price was awesome, 10$ for 3/4 lbs... Basically 2 meals worth!
author: brandon f.

description: Avoid as you see other patrons doing. Another disappointing experience of  inconsistency. Portions are based on the whim of the staff. Have been getting the chicken adobo and was served 2 pieces instead of 3 (this was the second time this happened). Flat our refused to accept my experience of coming here and ordering the same thing and getting 3.
author: Avik R.

description:
I saw this place and noticed under their fusion specialties "Sinigang Molasses Wings". By the sounds of it, it had to be tried. 

You get only two options when ordering  their Sinigang wings. 1) 6pc. Combo with garlic rice and pancit, $8.99. 2) 9pc. Wings (no sides), $10.99. Option 1 sounds like a better deal but I went with option 2 just to get greedy for three more chicken wings. 

Anyways, after a bite or two I couldn't  taste the "Sinigang" flavor, except the sourness.  I realized on the menu they used tamarind paste as the base of the wings, chipotle peppers, banana ketchup, soy sauce, sriracha sauce and molasses. 
I was kinda confused but they tasted like fried Korean sweet and sour chicken wings. But hey my family liked them. 

I noticed some of the reviews of this place were mediocre because people were comparing their home cooked meals versus theirs?! Be fair people! and stop hatin'! I really give Inay's some kudos for trying to make something different and cool like Sinigang wings? Yeah Sinigang wings! from that sour soup.

Friendly service here and they make some of their entrees fresh off the grill.

This place is located at the second floor in  Target City and is situated at the corner of the food court. 

3.5 stars!
author: Jon B.

description: Nice casual Filipino fare that covers a variety of regional Filipino cuisines. Price is decent for San Francisco. I loved my Bicol express and fried bangus belly.
author: Thaddeau E.

description:
I ordered the lumpia  and pancit a la carte at lunch today

The pancit  was bland with little hunks of salami? Some sort of weird chunks of dif meat.  Maybe pastrami?  I don't know, weird and cheap.

The lumpia were itty bitty sizes and boring

I probably ordered wrong but that's what I wanted while we watched the free concert outdoors at Yerba Buena gardens.  It was a fabulous opera singer from Sweden.
author: Foodlover B.

description: I got the Pork adobo & garlic rice meal thru Meal Pal, portion definitely looks bigger on meal pal. The garlic rice & noodle was good, the sauce of the pork adobo on the rice was really good but the pork itself is way too salty. I don't think I will get the pork adobo again but might try the other stuff out.
author: SuZy Q.

description: I never do reviews but I felt the need to do so. This was my 2nd time at Inay's. The older lady behind the cash register was nice and orderly however, the lady behind the counter handing food was rude and obviously irritated. I had ordered sisig fries with the siracha sauce but asked for the sauce in a separate container. She was rushing my order and threw the container in my hand. If you're irritated or annoyed, you shouldn't take it out on your customers. Aside from that, fry to sisig ratio was uneven and the egg barely saved it for me. Overall, terrible customer service so I will not be coming back.
author: Kim T.

description:
5 stars for 2 specific dishes - pork sisig over rice and the sisig fries 

I know they have a bunch of other things here but I'm not sure if I'll ever get anything else here. My colleague introduced us to the sisig rice here 2-3 years ago and now the bunch of us are hooked. 

It comes out to around $12 after tax and everything but it's so damn worth it. 

For the fries you probably don't want to finish it by yourself in one sitting. It's a lot. I don't like adding anything extra to it. 

For the rice but I usually finish it in one go although it's probably not the best idea. Make sure you get the vinegar and soy sauce for this dish. I like to put in all the vinegar they provide and usually only use half the soy sauce packet. Then I mix it all up. 

You get all the nice crispy fatty bits along with some cartilage (not meat, fat, nor solid bone - I have no idea). This could be a turn off but I like the variety. 

Anyway there's nothing quite like this dish and now I'm really hungry.
author: Jeff C.

description: I enjoyed Halo Halo drink (not sure the flavor but it was that Taro purple flavor). Also ordered the two entrees with BBQ chicken skewers and the Bicol Express. The skewers were normal but the Bicol pork was tasty and flavorful. It's a decent fast food restaurant.
author: Hoang N.

description: Ordered the special and we were told 10 minute wait. When our number was called we picked up the special and before opening the container there was an overwhelming fish smell. After the first bite it was evident fish oil was overly used to the point that it was inedible for me and my boyfriend only had about 5 bites. Here we are 20 min later and after coffee we still can't get the horrible taste out. This is unfortunate as we live just a 10 min walk from here and really wanted to like it.
author: Megan M.

description: Love Inay's kitchen! Little slice of home away from home. I love the Bicol express and garlic rice. Lechon can be a bit chewy and dry but overall I can't complain.
author: Shiela D.

description:
For fast food, this is ridiculously good. Ended up having two meals in one day here while I was visiting SF. 

Went with the lechon liempo both times. Also tried the sweet longanisa the first time. Longanisa wasn't anything special.  Just okay. 

The liempo though was amazing. Especially the first time because the server out it on the grill for a few minutes before serving it to me.   You can order that as part of combo for an additional $1 or a la carte at $10.49 for 3/4 of a pound. 

They also serve halo halo with your choice of use or mango ice cream.
author: Maria A.

description:
I was in SF attending a conference at the Moscone Convention Center and staying at the Marriott Marquis.  I get to SF a lot and used to live here, but rarely have stayed downtown for any length of time.  I was craving Filipino food and did a Yelp search, finding that Inay was right next to my hotel.  The reviews were less than raves, but I wanted to give it a try because I was hungry and it was so, so close.  It's in the food court at the Metreon, so there are other options, but I wanted Filipino food.

They have a steam table with 10 or so dishes available.  I asked the Tita behind the steam table what was especially good.  I asked about the dinaguan and then asked what was the best today.  I ended up with the pork adobo and garlic rice.  Yes, I know that you are not supposed to have garlic rice with adobo (steamed rice is traditional and provides a plainer canvass upon which the adobo is then the star), but the garlic rice looked and smelled heavenly so I had that.  I took it to go and went back to my hotel room.  And inhaled the food!  They were both quite delicious.

Over the next few days, I took several of my doctoral students there so that they could try Filipino food.  I also had the Bicol Express (yummy) and Lumpia Shanghai (tasty, but expensive).

So, like all things in life, you have to know what to order.  I liked this place a bunch and would go back.  It tends to be a little expensive, but at least you can get good Filipino food in a clean and warm setting.
author: Mark P.

description:
If you have a craving for Filipino food after shopping in Westfield mall, this is the place to go. It's conveniently located in the Metreon between Target and the movie theater.
Their BBQ on a stick is good and the portion is big. It's made to order so it's always tender and flavorful. 
They have a daily selection of Filipino favorites such as arroz caldo, adobo, lumpia, and pancit. You can't go wrong with any of them.
author: Stella M.

description:
As a Filipina-American, I tend to rate Filipino restaurants critically because NOTHING beats my mother's cooking.  And I'm sure every Filipino will say the same thing about their mother's cooking.  But Inay is a good substitute when I want Filipino food.

I ordered a combo of garlic rice, pancit, and a bbq chicken skewer.  It was around $10.  I wasn't a fan of the pancit, but the skewer was delicious.  The pancit, to me, didn't have much flavor and was a oily.  The skewer was a good chunk of meat with the right amount of sauce, grilled perfectly.  I wanted to try the turon (banana lumpia), but they had run out.

I think Inay is a nice addition to the dining options at the Metreon.  I feel what they offer is different from the other Asian restaurants.  It's hard to market Filipino food because the general population is unfamiliar with it.  But Inay does a good job of showcasing traditional dishes, and some fusion ones too.

And be careful with the plastic to-go box.  I cut myself trying to open it.  The edges are pretty sharp.
author: Vira P.

description: I see a lot of good reviews but the chicken adobo I had didn't taste like adobo. Tasted like regular gravy. It's not bad but it definitely didn't taste like adobo. Disappointing
author: Werd R.

description:
I've been curious about this restaurant for a while and finally decided to try it out. I ordered all fried rice and bicol express. I've got to say, it turned out to be very good! Especially the fried rice. One down side is that they possibly used MSG.

I normally eat Filipino food at Leelin (previously called Goldilocks) and I think I prefer it better. Leelin's much more affordable and better in quality. I feel that spending almost $10 for 1 item + rice is just way too much. I'd rather get sushi. And to top it off, most of Inay's items didn't look welcoming. I only ordered bicol express because it looked like the most popular - it was almost done while the other items looked untouched.
author: Jeanne P.

description: Could have been 4 stars, but due to bad customer service I'm giving this restaurant 2 stars. I was waiting on the grilling station side when my order was called at the counter. I raised my hand to just quickly grab the snack and go, but the lady serving at the counter made me go to her at the counter side and give me my order. I would understand if it was busy, but nobody was there ordering anyway.
author: C L.

description:
Rice - nasty they use cheap rice
Mongo- hella nasty! They use the same meat for sinigang. For some reason i feel like the left over sinigang they gonna rinse it nd put to monggo thats how disgusting i think this place.
BBQ- ok 
Lumpia- so expensive nd to small. Also under cook
Palabok- diagusting
Pork adobo- nasty

All their food nasty! I tried them all. 
They need a new CHEF ! FOREAL.  

This place need to close! Its so messy. I wanted to rate this 0 but i cant do that so. JUST DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY HERE! GO TO CHIPOTLE OR SOMEWHERE ELSE NOT HERE.
author: Lara J.

description: Food is ok here but giving one star as one lady who they employ there seemed so unhappy to be there. On my way to catch a movie I decide to stop by and grab a halo halo as it has been a while. I approach the counter and see there were three employees behind the counter, two guys filling a grill working and one lady leaning on the counter facing her back towards me on her phone, no other customers around, I stand there and she doesn't notice or hear me so I move around to catch them on their peripheral vision. The lady busy on her phone I wanted to ask, "so what's happening on Facebook" but decide no just give her a chance. One of the guys notices me and says "hello" to me and the lady then turns around annoyed and rolling eyes asks what I want. I order, pay then wait for my order to come. As she yelled my number I returned my plastic card containing my number they gave me and asked if she can throw away the receipt. She was about to reach for my receipt but then stopped and yelled "no!". There was a huge white garbage bin directly behind her for a tiny receipt. I have worked in customer service many years, I was thinking ok maybe I'm arriving and they are about to close. I check online when they close and they still had 1.5 hours. Even when I had bad days I know I'm representing a business and carry on a face and try and provide the best experience for customers so they return. Clearly this was not on her mind. So not sure if she was just annoyed I came to order and disrupted her phone time or perhaps maybe I reminded her of someone she didn't like? Or maybe the restaurant has a policy that they cannot throw away receipts? No idea --but 1 star for customer service, and 5 star for the halo halo here.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Omg, had the most watery, pale, tasteless palabok I've ever had in my life!! (And I've had a lot) I've had this dish once before here and was underwhelmed but thought, hell they are Filipino, they can be that bad at cooking this consistently, so I thought it was a one off... Nope! This time around was the absolute worse it can get. They just seriously need to remove this from the menu all together.... 

The 2 stars because the bbq sticks are on point and the lechon dishes look imaginative and would like to try those... Hmmm...
author: Helen P.

description: I can understand why this restaurant has a three-star rating. I have been curious to try it for a while now, as I pass it every time I go to see a movie at the Metreon. I stopped in for a quick dinner on a Tuesday night, and ordered the pork sisig. Many of the choices they have are not prepared fresh, however, the sisig is. Still, I was not too impressed with the food. It was okay, but seemed to lack any originality. The presentation was good, but it seemed like there wasn't much effort put into it. Kind of your typical food-court-type restaurant.
author: Andrew L.

description: Best Filipino food I've been able to find in downtown SF! Love their chicken adobo
author: Christina J.

description: It's okay... I might have enjoyed it more if I went heavier in the carbs with pancit, etc. It was  as good as you're going to get for "cheap", quick work lunch in the Metreon (bill was still close to $15). I got the Bangus fish, which is an additional $2.50 more than 1 or 2 item combo plate, and the kale salad. The fish was pretty delicious! It was dense, tasted like salted fish, fishier than I normally like, but the bottom grilled portion was crispy and savory. The mango salad on top didn't look very fresh so I pushed it aside, and I didn't think the fish needed any enhancement. The kale salad was okay... as good as salads go, the homemade dressing was pretty sweet, but light and unique tasting.
author: Ke C.

description:
ordered 8 pieces of lumpias and a pork sisig

lumpias: 3/5 they were much smaller than i expected and werent that crunchy. tasted like it was left heated for a while

pork sisig: 4/5 it came with garlic rice, fried egg, diced bell peppers, onions, and mangoes. there was a lot of pork, but i wished it evened out with the rice or the rice had more. this is kinda spicy, but tasted rlly good. this is a pretty big meal, i finished a lil more than half

sisig fries: egg, salsa, onions, mangoes, and thousand island sauce. tasted mostly like animal fries from in n out but with different fries and meat

overall, even tho the food was kinda good, this wouldn't be my first filipino place to go to. kinda over priced for its quality
author: Amy L.

description: Portions are now plentiful and I usually get the pork menudo and half white rice and pancit. You can get their grilled bbq all year around, I say this because I always look forward to the grilled meats during festival season and I found out the grilled meats come from Inay.
author: Sarah T.

description:
It's often hard to judge Filipino food because my mom and aunties are such amazing cooks! Pancit, adobo, menudo, sinigang and tinola - they have the Filipino food game down, pat.  And those are just the common dishes, we didn't even go to the dinuguan, kare kare, caldereta, bistek, sisig, bulalo, and those more "special occasion dishes"..they whip those up with ease, too. (OMG, I'm making myself hungry.) 

That said, Inay Filipino Kitchen is A-OK.  Missed the marks on some dishes, but have to give them credit for bringing Filipino food to a super mainstream locale. Nice they have several dishes turo turo (point point/buffet counter) style of both the common and more labor intensive/special occasion dishes.  And I'll give them credit for some of their attempts to do Filipino fusion with their lechon nachos, sinigang wings and sisig fries.  If I was feeling adventurous, I would have at least tried the sinigang wings as they are coated with molasses and are said to be spicy and tamarind flavored. (Next time na lang.)

Here's what I ordered: 

- Chicken adobo - kinda went basic here because if your chicken adobo isn't good then you're in trouble.  Well, it was good, but I've had better.  As in I can cook it better.  It lacked the vinegar and garlic flavor.  And don't get me started about no whole peppercorns and bay leaf in sight.  Missed the mark there, Inay.

- Pork menudo was better!  Way more flavorful with the red pepper and extra saucy.  Pork and veggies were well seasoned and incorporated in the dish well, but where was the liver?  I guess that's too hardcore.  Still, I'd order it again.

- Tofu adobo was something my dining companion ordered and I'd be remiss if I didn't relay her thoughts on the dish.  Not recognizable to me, I asked the friendly male server what it was.  He said "adobong tofu".  Okay, I thought great - she didn't have many other non-pork dishes to try and it looked quite good with the melange of inviting veggies (string beans and bok choy was it)...and the jalapeno that sat atop the mound suggested there could be a kick to it.  Boy, was she disappointed.  They should have mentioned it also contained pork, which means the sauce probably tasted of pork, too.  

My suggestion would be to label the dishes and maybe list some of the ingredients for the non-Filipino patrons. And even the Filipino patrons would likely welcome signs as not all Filipino dishes are created equally.  My family is from Pampanga - known to be the best cooks in all of the Philippines (and where all the most beautiful women in the PI reside..ahem) - so my palate for Filipino food was refined from the start.  Again, my mom and aunties are some of the best Filipino food cooks out there.  And I've been to Pampanga before and their cooking was on par with all food that I consumed in the(ir) motherland.

But I've digressed... I would go back to Inay for the menudo.  I'd love to try their arroz caldo on a cold day or when I'm battling a cold, and other mainstays such as their sinigang and sisig.  Prices are average for Filipino turo turo - 2 items with garlic fried rice or pancit for just over $10.00 and they give generous portions.  Service was quick and friendly, albeit they didn't mention the tofu dish had pork.  Three stars, A-OK in my (opinionated) book.
author: Marie B.

description: Great food and great people! Every time I try something new I'm always pleased that I made that choice! Highly recommended!
author: Aleksandr A.

description:
I'm sure there's great Filipino food out there, and my utter lack of familiarity with that cuisine led me to give it a try at this fast food spot in the Metreon food court. But the combination of good food and the Metreon is just not a marriage that seems to be working judging from what I've had here and at Via Moto (review: http://bit.ly/1cqDRiC). There's just something doggedly mediocre about almost everything I get in this food court with the sole exception being the Spicy Tofu Stew with Seafood at Sorabol (review: http://bit.ly/1dsmvmC). I also have to admit that the lackluster service didn't make a great impression on me as I waited a while to order and then waited quite a while to get my order even though I ordered off their own regular menu.

I tried the $7.49 Inay's Salad Bowl with BBQ Chicken which was blandly generic except for the refreshing chopped mango on top (photo: http://bit.ly/1a6ZENN). I was expecting something a bit more distinctive in flavor though, and I might as well have gotten a burrito bowl at Chipotle for the same price. As a side dish, I went for the $3.49 container of Mini-Arroz Caldo, which sounded promising since it looked like jook (photo: http://bit.ly/186PbkT). It was most definitely rice porridge with chunks of processed-tasting chicken from what I could tell. There was a sliced hard-boiled egg which I felt was texturally at odds with the porridge, and the spring onions was the only element that lent freshness to the concoction. I probably need to get myself to Daly City for the good stuff.

FOOD - 2 stars...stubbornly bland food doesn't seem to do justice to what may be an interesting cuisine
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...it's the Metreon, for Pinoy's sake
SERVICE - 1.5 stars...disinterested
TOTAL - 2 stars...another Metreon misfire
author: Ed U.

description:
What I ate: Bistek, pinakbet, pancit, garlic fried rice, calamansi juice
Visit date: October 3, 2013
First time? Yes.

Surprisingly good! I'm really picky when it comes to restaurant Filipino food. Inay wasn't so bad.

I wish the bistek was more tender, and that they would cook the onions through a bit more, but the salty/sour flavors were spot on. The pinakbet I didn't really care for (it's one of my favorites so I'm extra picky about it), nor the pancit (the noodles were too smooshy), but the garlic fried rice is a must! It's salty and garlicky, but not the kind of garlicky that leaves a lingering back taste. Also, I recommend finishing off your meal with some refreshing calamansi juice. Think lemonade, but more awesome.
author: Erin G.

description: I've only been here for the sisig fries and it's pretty good but not to the extremes of for example Chibog or Señor Sisisg. I've heard from a handful of people as well that the food they have tried such as the adobo or chicken bbq skewers are okay, nothing quite special. Maybe I have to experience it for myself and order something to base a review on besides sisig fries?
author: Stacey M.

description:
Fairly average Filipino food- but decent enough for downtown SF. It's a better bet to go to Daly City or Oakland where there is a more significant Filipino population and higher quality Pinoy cuisine.

I ordered the Bangus and Garlic rice. The bangus was somewhat dry, but not too bad altogether. What I do remember is that I paid too much for this meal and would've been better off ordering food at one of the other places in the food court that Inay Filipino Kitchen is located in.
author: Ramon Miguel F.

description:
Anyone who knows me knows my roster of fave foods is like a who's-who of the sickest, barfworthiest, Fear Factorest dishes from around the globe. Let's get an abbreviated recap...

Korea: Beondegi (chrysalis), Golbaengi Muchim (snails), Yukhwe

Japan: Whatever that entrail shotglass was from Kappou Gomi

China: Chicken Feet, Blood Cubes, Snails Again

Africa: Grubs, Slimy Yet Satisfying, Timon & Pumbaa

USofA: Livers & Gizzards, Pickled Pigs' Feet, Donut Burgers

...Which brings us to the Philippines. Ever since I was little, my two most loved foods from this cuisine have been Balut (duck egg w/ embryo) and Dinuguan (pig ears stewed in pig blood).

Dinuguan was the sole reason I decided to eat at Inay's. I wasn't sure if there were ears in mine; either that or they weren't cut chunky enough. No matter. I still want more.

But I'll no longer mess around with the 2-item combo - I'm just going to get 1 item, and a lot of it. In fact, I can skip the rice and pancit too, especially since I didn't have lemon or chicharron for the pancit. Just give me like a liter of the dinuguan, a drink, and a spork.
author: Dan B.

description:
I came by looking for a small bite to eat to hold me over until I could get back to work and eat my lunch. They had a small assortment of traditional food and it looked pretty good, so I opted to try their Lumpia. Boy, oh boy! It was really good, with the right amount of flavor. 

The price: 4 for about $2.65
author: Sylvia O.

description: How does it take 20 min to place an order, pay, and get your food when there's no one in line and all the food is already made? And what is the point in giving me a number when they're not going to use it for anything? They gave me a number and then my food sat there for 5 min because they didn't know they should give it to the only person holding a number. I can't even handle this level of stupidity.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Not bad for food court standard. The taste is on the salty side but acceptable. The garlic rice is good. The adobo is good. And today I tried their bitter melon dish and it was really really good! (But only if you like bitter melon. It's an acquired taste so be warned.)

Last but not least, the portion is pretty generous!
author: Joseph L.

description: Everything I've had here has been delicious. I love adobo and Lechon Liempo! Want to try others.
author: Chris M.

description:
I've never really understood why Vietnamese people were so critical when it came to eating pho until now.

I grew up eating Filipino food and I completely understand that home cooked meals will always be better, but this place is not that good at all. I've tried multiple items on their list, but it just doesn't taste like anything but salt and oil. Maybe I'm just being too critical, but it was a disappointment.

3 stars because the only thing I enjoyed here was the arozcaldo. lol
author: Pj A.

description: I've had better at my parents' house or filipino parties. That's usually always the case when I eat at filipino places lol. Since I'm not familiar with cooking filipino dishes I like ordering here now and then. I don't like how they just bark at me in Tagalog assuming I can understand them.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Ordered pancit palabok, breakfast platter (2-items), and sisig fries. With one can of coconut juice the total came to $34.32. The pancit palabok was ok but I was not offered lemon. The breakfast platter was hit and miss. The longanisa was great, but the tocino was fatty and low-quality meat.

 I asked for ketchup and was told curtly that they didn't have any. This is a fast food takeout, not a Michelin-star restaurant. The older lady was very friendly. The younger lady was a bit aloof. 

If you want a good breakfast platter and you don't mind going upstairs for condiments, I'd say this is a great place. I'd also recommend the pancit palabok.
author: Dale T.

description: Had a horrible experience ordering Bagoong fried rice.  The meat was gooey with too much liquid (pink) bagoong sauce, it was hardly fried rice. The mango salad was not fresh. When I approached the manager about how salty and gooey the bagong fried rice was and that the mango salad was not fresh, she was very defensive (she didn't speak tagalog and couldn't communicate well about the authenticity of the dishes) and blamed the servers.  It was not really the servers fault, it was the ingredients and the recipe! I've never been so dissapointed as I was.  Overpriced, ultra-fast food with no heart or soul (This is hardly Filipino or Malay). Too bad! Bagoong fried rice is exceptional when prepared well - It's Southeast Asian connection (with Indonesia) are magic combo of flavors.  Not here!  The food seemed to come out of a money-making business taking advantage of its prime location at the metreon...I was not able to taste the culture or amazing flavors of this dishes influences that could have been...Will not go back after the way the manager handled the situation. I paid 16$ ++ (food and drink). Felt horrible after. I thought I'd feel better after talking to the manager, it made the experience worse.  You know how a bad meal can ruin your day? This was definitely one of those.
author: Shu K.

description:
I was excited to try their dinuguan (innards stewed in pig's blood) but alas, it was greasy and didn't have enough sourness to cut through the blood. In fact, it was salty too. 

Pinakbet was ok (veggies in shrimp paste) but the garlic rice was really yum!

The best Filipino food I've had? at my mom's kitchen!
author: Janice C.

description: Masarap! Filipino food is hard to come by in the U.S. if you don't have a real inay (mother) to cook it for you. This Inay didn't disappoint (except they didn't have pinakbet that day). The bangus (grilled fish) and lechon (roast pork with crispy skin) were both delicious.
author: Gajah D.

description: Average Filipino food. Extra star for munggo (mung bean stew). Pleasant staff.
author: Inigo M.

description: Typical Filipino restaurant. They are only good when their newly open. The staff in front today is no good.She simply ignores my questions in regards to ordering food. But I notice, if its not Filipino, she seemed so nice. Never again.
author: Gracie P.

description: By far, one of my favorite Filipino cuisine spot in San Francisco. I love the location because it is inside the shopping center with a movie theater, and lose to Share Tea and other restaurants. The food is very tasty and delicious for a reasonable price. I come here occassionally whenever I crave for Filipino food.
author: Dan Mark D.

description:
This is fast-food food-court Filipino food. No effin lie! 
Or is it past-pood pood-court Pilipino pood? No eppin lie! Pinoy or Pinay!

It is inside the Metreon, right near the ticket booths for the AMC theaters. They have most of your Filipino typical favorites. If you come late, near closing time (near 9pm) they will give you 30% discount off of your meal. 

I like the family photos that are part of the wall decorations behind the counter. Family is important in Filipino culture, and this place is affordable for a family. It has to be. All my old Filipino friends were one of 7 kids average!  And lots of Cousins! 

I had a combo plate that was HUGE. I couldn't eat more than half of it, and I am not shy, so there was enough for 2, maybe 3. If things are tough por you, maybe it was enough to peed the whole pamily!?

I had Kare Kare (peanut based sauce) and Pork Adobo (vinegar based flavors) and another main with my Pancit (sort of Filipino Chow Mein but with finer noodles). 

A lot of meat! And grease! Aren't those the two main ingredients in good Filipino food?

Now if they had a Karaoke machine, dance floor for youtube videos, and San Miguel Beers here, everything would be complete (and Pinoy!)
author: Wanugee N.

description:
I don't know why people don't like this place! 

I really like their arroz caldo, lechon sisig (it's basically lechon kawali cut into tiny pieces with rice and tomatoes), lechon kawali (like a rolled up pork belly so very flavorful), pansit. The Bicol express is okay too, if you're craving for it. 

Service is a bit slow though, and they take their time but they're accommodating.
author: Rae C.

description: I came solely for the arroz caldo. I don't have many expectations about it because I've had variations made. Not impressed with this place. The previous reviews swore by the porridge and I can't even taste anything. The chicken addition of $3 should've been more than what I was given. More like $1 worth. They didn't have lemon or soy sauce included in my delivery which sort of bummed me out, but I know I should've asked for it or something. I just kind of assumed it'd be together. All in all, the porridge is bland, definitely not worth the $11.
author: Tricia M.

description:
I love coming here when I'm downtown. The portions are very filling, and a 1-item combo is usually more than enough. I typically order sisig fries, pancit palabok, or a combo with lechon, chicken adobo, or the mongo (lentil stew).  All their dishes are delicious.  And I'm excited to try their palabok fries since palabok sauce is a dream for seafood lovers.

I only give 4 stars because I've had a few bad experiences. It's usually because I got there late in the day and the items were stale. But you can see which ones look old, so if you choose what looks fresh or order off of the menu, then you'll always have great food.

For what it's worth, I'd just like to say that I miss some of the dishes that they removed from their everyday menu a long time back: specifically the kare kare and the dinuguan. But I understand the decision because they have to boot what doesn't get ordered (see stale-food comment above) and I like to see that they strive to improve.
author: Justin L.

description: I used to love coming here, especially because I work around the corner. I ordered the sinigang and lechon. Later on in the evening, I got really bad food poisoning and I thought I was going to die. I know it's from here because it's the only thing I ate yesterday. I think their food isn't fresh and they might reuse old dishes until they spoil without checking. What a shame. I love Filipino food. I'll never be coming back.
author: Rachel D.

description: The food is great, but customer service is what brings customers back. I'm never coming here physically again. Horrid customer service.
author: Daniel G.

description: Hard to find Filipino food. This place is solid and they even have over easy eggs on garlic rice with longinisa for that next day hangover fix. Going to be a regular spot.
author: Edward K.

description: Food is okay but damn, hella jacked up price! First and last time here.
author: Oliver C.

description:
Unfortunately, there is no zero star.  Please do not eat here!!!  My friend and I ordered "bangus" because it is Ash Wednesday.  We got sick/food poisoned after an hour - almost got hospitalized.  The bangus was burnt outside and might not be cooked well inside.  Also, I saw them taking out the bangus from a plastic bag.  I hope Department of Health will come by and check this place.  After that incident, it scares me to eat in a restaurant.  

Food is expensive too.
author: GeeDee G.

description:
(See pics) Review #1272. A relaxing area to rest your feet and carb up after shopping next door at Target.

Bangus (fish)  belly was with decent fish taste even it's a bit dry probably because it's sitting on the warming plate for a while. Get half noodles and half garlic fried rice.

The pork adobo (stew) was with richly flavored especially when I heated it up later on as the second part of lunch. Generally food court food was just never hot enough to eat when you get it but reheating works the best to bring out the ingredients.

They also have halo halo, something to definitely get at the next visit as well as other Filipino dishes. Why? Because I saw a lot of Filipinos eating there and we all know it's an authentic sign.
author: T L.

description:
My co-worker and I thought Filipino food was pancit, lumpia and chicken adobo.  We both wanted to expand our horizon and taste other things but didn't know how to.  So, we nominated our client/friend, our closest to Filipino person we know.  We told him that we wanted to be in the passenger seat while he drives the food selection for us.  And then he said sure and recommended the pancit, lumpia and chicken adobo (lol).

As we meet up at the Metreon food court, our friend explained what was good, what the flavors were and what his wife likes to eat.  Since his wife likes it, we would probably like it too!

All 3 of us ordered entree 2.  Just because we wanted to test more than 1 selection.
1) Garlic rice, pancit, bangus belly (fish belly), Kara Kara (peanut butter curry oxtail stew)
2) Garlic rice, pancit, sour pork soup, blood cube stew
3) Garlic rice, pancit, Kara Kara, pork stew

It came with shrimp paste.  One whiff of that will make you faint!  I put a micro dab of it on my tongue and first it was salty, then very pungent, and BAM! The shrimp flavor snuck in.  Ohh...it was too powerful for me to handle.  I put it away...

I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed my dishes if bangus belly!  They actually heated it up for me first.  If you put the mango chutney and vinegar on top, it's like a party in your mouth.  My only complaint, the fish was too dry and that was because I ate it without the mango/vinegar.  Make sure to slather that stuff on before eating it.  The Kara Kara has a light sweetness to it and the oxtail melted in my mouth.  But what really made my mouth happy was the garlic rice.  All 3 were virgin bites for me and it was very tasty!  

My co-worker let me taste her sour pork soup...and again!! virgin bites made my mouth happy!  The soup tasted like a Chinese pork bean soup with a sour pizazz!  As for the blood cubes, I couldn't even look at it.  Maybe I'll be more daring next time.

Inay...I'll be back for seconds, thirds, fourths... Great food, good service, and good location!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Inay is hidden near the elevator,. it's across from sogreen. they sells premade Filipino food from a steam table. about 16 entrees listed.
main feature: 1 entree combo, 7.95,  2 entree,combo 9.98?

eats: shanghai lumpia (4 .29), 8 minipieces
-came with sweet & sour sauce, best part of the meal (yep, the sauce)
-lumpia kind of soggy, not crispy (being under the heatlamps didn't help)
-filling bland, no taste, probably came  frozen, available at ranch 99, seafood center
2 stars.

crumbs:
-service ok, someone just grabbed and packaged lumpia from under the sun lamps.
-other foods just scoop and serve.
-many employees, few customers.
author: Victor G.

description:
I have been here once and the food as good. I had the sinagang and it was fine. It was a little pricey, but I expected that since it is paying Metreon rent.  The service was pretty good, but when I first came up it too a bit for folks to notice I was there. That's fine, but it does seem like they are not up the same service and feel as some of the other places there. My guess is the the cliental is not going to as easy going as if this were located in a Daly City storefront, so they may need to step it up a bit.

That said, I will go back because I do think it's awesome that there is a Filipino restaurant in such a visible location and I want them to succeed.
author: Bruce R.

description: My squad and I came to chill and get some bomb ass sisig fries. At lunch time, we ordered 3. They said it would take 1 HOUR. I'm mad
author: Andy F.

description:
You would think that after being opened for almost two years and possibly reading the reviews.... This place might've improved. Nope :/

The prepared food looked like it wasn't touched for the entire day... It looked kinda gross. We decided to get the sisig fries since it would be made fresh. The fries were okay, nothing special or worth the money in my opinion. Would've gladly taken my time and money elsewhere. I will probably never come here again. Despite the food being okay, I hate going to places that don't pride in good customer service and have disinterested and clueless workers. Maybe when the workers actually know what they're doing, learn how to operate a business or even seem one bit interested in keeping a customer's business will I consider coming back.
author: Cindy C.

description: I grew up in Manila, Philippines and this is exactly how Filipino food should be. The food is great and theirs actually tastes like the high-end Filipino restaurants in the Manila. I always go to this place once a week and I always pig out when I am here. The only bad thing I can say is that it is too far from my place of work, I hope I can eat at this everyday.
author: Aileen Grace S.

description: Just picked up 8 pieces of lumpia and they're really really good (small, but good), some of the employees' English isn't the best but I got my point across and they are nice.
author: Alison C.

description:
Sorry The Food here looks like it's been left out and untouched for Ages sitting around on heat lamps or something, I wouldn't bother eating this food. it looks disgusting and not Very fresh. Sad representation of Filipino foods considering there is such a substantial population of Filipinos in SF.... Not only is the food of compromised quality but it is over priced and unappealing, like most of the food Eateries IN the Metreon that just don't seem to work as well as Westfield does.

Sorry skip it & go have lunch in Westfield instead.
author: Julian I.

description:
After watching a movie at the AMC theaters upstairs in the Metreon, I discovered this place wandering the food court area. It was probably the Filipino in me, but I didn't have to think twice about eating here based on the food/name itself.

Now that I'm thinking about it, lately I've been eating a lot of fries (see other reviews) and I have my boyfriend to blame. So, of course, I ordered the Sisig Fries. 

Let me throw in some Wikipedia for those of you who don't know what "Sisig" is:
Sisig is a Kapampangan term which means "to snack on something sour". It usually refers to fruits, often unripe or half-ripe, sometimes dipped in salt and vinegar. It also refers to a method of preparing fish and meat, especially pork, which is marinated in a sour liquid such as lemon juice or vinegar, then seasoned with salt, pepper and other spices.

So in this case, it's the vinegar tasty pork with the fries. For $9.00, the portion for these fries are worth it (enough for 2 people share). On top of that, they are sooooo good!!! In addition to the Sisig, there's tomatoes, onions, jalapeno, mango bits, and a yummy sauce! 

Like any food court, they have a decent sized seating area to enjoy your food.

Four stars for the fries!!
author: Sammie T.

description: A for effort! Although not perfect you can find decent food at a decent price here. (remember you will be sitting in the Metreon eating and chilling with no pressure to leave right after eating.) I recommend the sisig with garlic rice, boiled ballot egg's (3 for $10) and the halo halo with mango ice cream is the bomb. I would also suggest if you have any issues just speak to Manny the Manager who can fix it for you with an excellent attitude. Is it the Philapines? Of course not silly but it is a decent place to grab a bite and chill for a minute before or after a movie. Oh by the way I'm Mexican/ American born in Chi- Town by way of Oak- Town baby!
author: Wayne A.

description:
I was excited to see Filipino representation in the ground floor food court of the Metreon. I decided to give it a try to get my Filipino-food mix and support a local Filipino business. 

I ordered a 2-item combination plate for about $10. Their selections were very meat-heavy. Today, they had kare kare, menudo, pork adobo, dinuguan, paksiw lechon, bicol's express, chopstuey, tofu & vegetables, and beef caldareta.  I was able to get half steamed white rice, and half pancit plus 2 items: beef caldareta and kare kare. My coworkers ordered bicol's express, pancit and a side of lumpia.

The food was ok. It's not the best Filipino food you'll ever have, but it was decent. I didn't have anything that blew me away, but at the same time, I didn't have anything that I thought was plain terrible or disgusting. I would definitely come back to try more things, especially if I was craving Filipino food in Union Square.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I'm not Filipino... But I ate here 2 days in a row and the employees are very nice. So... I'm going to go ahead and give them 4 stars even though, after reading all the the reviews, it seems the majority doesn't share my opinion that this place is awesome. 

Ate here out of pure convenience since it's in the  same building as target. 


Kare Kare and pork skewer. Awesome!
author: Michael A.

description:
Waste of time...

These people are inEFFICIENT.  Their process of taking orders includes skipping people who are next in line.  In addition their food looks old and has been sitting for "at least" a day.  They were good when they opened, which makes sense, it's face value at the time.   But now they are just awful, the meat taste old, the chicken is hard, the BBQ is either salty or sweet-never good.  

I DO NOT RECOMMEND!!!!!!
author: Honest F.

description: sooooooo this place isn't really that good. I actually hate their fried rice, it's the driest thing ever. I do, however like the pork sinigang and the lumpia Shanghai. I only went here multiple times because it helps my cravings and it's so convenient in this busy shopping area... But if I was given a choice of other Filipino restaurants, this would be my last pick.
author: Jason S.

description:
Ugh! I should have checked the reviews on this place first. I can't believe I ate even half of that thing they called pork adobo.

As some of the other reviews have mentioned (as I read it while I'm eating) the rice is half cooked. I know that most Filipinos know how to cook good rice, so why the hard rice? In a hurry for the lunch time convention center rush? Most likely, but for the pork adobo to be that off in flavor, so not right. 

I have to admit I settled to eat at this place being in a time crunch to squeeze in something to eat, but truthfully I wouldn't recommend even then.

Sorry "Inay" but your kitchen certainly doesn't taste like a Filipino kitchen
author: Riz B.

description: I only get one thing here...the Sisig Fries and they're really good. I can't speak for the other dishes, except the lumpia I got which was a bit disappointing; thus, the 3-star review. However, the Sisig Fries were yummy, well seasoned, flavorful, and had a good serving of pork on top. My go-to place for a snack before a movie at the Metreon.
author: Becky C.

description: Found this place by accident while browsing Yerba Buena Garden. The pork adobo was awesome. A bit too much fat on the meat for my liking but other than that I love it!!
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
Got the chicken skewers - thought they were just okay but I probably tried more authentic dishes. The chicken was wrapped in folk by the time i got home the sauce leaked everywhere - not sure why they didn't just put it in the container.

The pancit was a bit bland - mostly noodles and not much of anything else. 

Other than that - the portions were generous and service was friendly. 

I'd def go back and try some other dishes.
author: Mimi T.

description: I've been to Inay on a few different occasions, and I have to say it wasn't until my third time that I finally decided it might be better to look elsewhere for affordable lunch options in the Financial District. It's not that the food isn't good, but the prices are extremely expensive. For a one-item combo - longanisa with garlic rice, one 12 ounce container of Bicol Express, and a canned mango drink, I spent $22. At that price, I swallowed my pride and sucked it up. It's not like the prices were advertised anywhere. My coworker and I were looking all around for how much their meals were, but couldn't find any information. Since we had to hurry back to the office, pricing wasn't such a big deal anymore. I cannot justify spending this much on lunch. Had I gotten 2 combo meals, maybe yes, but I ordered one combo, one a la carte dish (no rice), and a drink. ONE drink. The food is good, but not anything fantastic.. I've definitely found food equal to or a lot better than what I've had at Inay's.
author: Monica M.

description: First of all, my friends and I went here to get some sisig fries. The cashier said it will take an hour for them to prep the meat. We were infuriated because as we went back 25 minutes later and we saw the chef making sisig fries for another customer. So we asked if it was ready and she said yes. So basically she kinda lied to us. It didn't take an hour. When our food was ready, the sisig fries were so good but you got to watch for those thai chili peppers. Overall the food was good but the service wasn't that great.
author: Bailey C.

description: The sisig fries are SOOOOOO good! They really hook you up and don't skimp on the meat! This + boba from Sharetea + people watching outside by Yerba Buena garden. I gotta come back and try the lechon nachos.
author: Jerald B.

description: Best Filipino fast food restaurant by far than Goldilocks!!!  Fast and friendly service!!!!  Highly recommended!!!  Reasonable price and clean environment!!  Friendly staff. Enjoy!!
author: Beth S.

description:
If you're craving Filipino food and Senor Sisig is not in the proximity, give Inay's a try! 

During lunchtime, when I have time to stroll around Yerba Buena, I like to stop by Inay's for my filipino cravings. I usually order the Sisig and garlic rice. The rice is a little bland and dry but the sisig was ok. I mean it was from the mall food court so don't expect gourmet dishes. -- But I can see why people are giving this place low stars. To me, the food was decent. The price I think was a little much...but they give you big portions. I believe I normally pay close to $11 bucks for sisig and garlic rice however, at senor sisig, I pay $2 less and the quality is a lot better. Anyways, will probably stop by here again if I'm desperately craving sisig.
author: Julia K.

description: They ain't great but they ain't terrible either. You can get an affordable combination platter of Filapino food.  The best thing about Inay Filapino is that they're across the street from Moscone Center West and during a large conference, it's convenient to get to here and back to the conference. They tend to be less busy than the other places in the Metreon complex, not sure if that's a sign of their food attractiveness vs the other places to eat or maybe it's just because they're tucked in an odd corner of the food court.
author: Albie F.

description:
I'm really happy I found out about this place, my lunch routine was getting really stale.  This is a much preferred alternative to Panda Express.  As far as I can tell, the food is pretty authentic (for filipino fast food), with extremely generous portions for the price.  I will certainly be back, as many of the items here look really great.

They have Sisig fries!!
author: Mike L.

description:
Update:

I was craving for pork sisig again and the nearest Filipino restaurant to my office was Inay. I thought I give it another try. Again, I'm disappointed. This times, my sisig order was super salty and greasy. On top of that, I got food poising from it. I'm never going back to this place - food and service sucks!!!!  I will just have to make that drive to Daly City if I want good Filipino food.
author: Karina T.

description: Such a novice experience. I came here and payed a ridiculous amount of money for very low quality Filipino food.
author: Leslie M.

description: My family was excited to find Filipino Cuisine inside the Metreon so we decided to try it out (unfortunately, before checking Yelp). There was no line and the 6 of us knew what we wanted. As we were ordering, a line started to form behind us and there was only 1 worker. She took all of our orders and got our 5 drinks herself but it was so awkward to stand there waiting to pay while she got all of our drinks with a line behind us. Another worker decided to help and started taking orders from the next customer. After we paid for what I feel was overpriced Filipino food, we sat in the small food court area at their small tables and ate. Their Chicken Adobo wasn't very Adobo like. It was more Iike Chicken in gravy. The rice was also mixed with something. It wasn't regular steamed rice. And their fountain drinks seems like they were homemade. She said it was "Pepsi brand" but they didn't have the normal labels and not much variety. All in all, I won't be back. And a little sad that this is how people will think Filipino food tastes.
author: Angelique L.

description:
Been going to Metreon every Wednesday evening since I have class at City College accross the street. 

I've held my review in hopes that it was a fluke of timing and after 4 Wednesdays I can officially say that this filipino fastfood is over priced, over cooked, and their staff on Wednesday evening are the worst.

We ordered Pork Sisig at 6:00pm and askd the lady how long to cook it.  She mentioned it will only take 5 minutes (to heat this up).  Ok...

We saw that she started prepping the to go Box and placed it next to the Cooking Area.  Heard her say the order to the cook.  So we waited.....waited....and waited. then there was a crowd that ordered to go....I would say roughly 15 people got their orders.

And we waited....25 mins later we flagged down the server and asked her where is our order...She was saying..Oh a few more minute.  WHAT THE EFF!!!  Can you please check????  She then hurried in the back and then replied to us....Its coming  they are just cooking the egg.  At this point...I lost it.  I told her forget it and want my money back.  She replied...we are already cooking it and should be out in a minute.

Then I heard laughing by the kitchen and then mentioned that she has NOT put in the orders request.  AHHHHH!!!!  My hopes of Inay being a good representative of Filipino Cuisine has gone down the drain.

In Fairness here are my Rating:

Food - 3 Stars (nothing Extra ordinary)
Ambiance - 3 Stars 
Price - 1 star (Too Expensive for mediocre Filipino Food)
Service - ZERO Stars!!!! Worst service in SF.  Being in a Foodie Bay Area ..Inay better get their act together.
author: SFoodie P.

description:
The best items on their menu are the arroz caldo and sisig fries because they're served warm. Oh, and their ube ice cream served in pan de sal brings me back to my childhood.

This restaurant is turo-turo style (under food warmers) and I've had food served to me that wasn't quite warm. Really nothing special. There are much better eateries in the Metreon.
author: Catalina C.

description:
This place is alright. It's a Filipino fast food place and definitely fulfills your Filipino food cravings in the area since Jollibee shut down just a block away from here. Most fast-food places would get a 3-star rating from me because of how their food is prepared. But since this place is basically in a food court in a mall, I would say that a 3-star rating is actually good. Most food court places are just unappetizing to me. 

If you know Filipino food, this place should suffice. If you don't know Filipino food, don't let this place be the first place you try it.
author: Rylan C.

description:
With 2 or 3 staff in front; service just can't get any faster can't they?

Visited them twice both were ok. Though they do like to chit chat more with pure breed Filipinos than to actually try to serve all their customers. I on my last visit, I ordered Kare Kare which is almost like stew, but the woman gave me the wrong dish. 

The squash on my food was a bit too big, and they should cut them smaller into a bite size portion. 

I paid nearly $10 for a one item dish but that is understandable considering how expensive the rent is for the Metreon.
author: RICHARD A.

description:
YUCK! What the hell is this food??? Top of the worse Filipino food we ever ate hands down!

Do I have to give one star? I wish I can give ZERO star. Food is very bland, VERY oily, and did I forget horrible.

I hope they change their seasoning or their chef. As a Filipino, I definitely want to eat tasty and very flavorful Filipino dishes, you will not find it here, unfortunately.
author: Romer C.

description: The worst fast food Filipino place I've ever gone to.  To top it off the food is very expensive and so not with it if you want a quick stomach ache.  The pork menudo was terrible.  I will never go back there again.
author: Terry S.

description: The garlic rice was ehh. I ordered the molasses fried chicken wings, but it tasted like the chicken was in the fryer too long or there was too much sauce.
author: Cindy H.

description: This  is my first Filipino restaurant / food court review! It's expensive for the first part , maybe due to the rental fee. Its inside Metreon!  For the food the pork BBQ on a skewer I like it, tender not overly cooked and there is still have a distinct filipino taste which is on the sweeter side! But the Pancit ( noodle dish) and pork menudo (it's different from Mex Menudo)  this is kinda stew with tomato sauce and the protein is pork meat! I'm not impressed I can cook way better than what they serve! The latter two you can find that on the food corner where bus stops in the Philippines!
author: Bu I.

description:
In all fairness, it's really hard to convey real good home made Filipino food into a commercialized restaurant type-of-a-deal. Every Filipino and their Inay (Mother) is going to say my Inay, Itay (aka Dad), Tito, Tita etc. cooks the best Filipino food, so why is your Inay's better?

Well I ask the same thing. I ordered something out of the ordinary...a Salad--a Filipino salad to be exact topped with all the Filipino toppings you could ask for. I know, you ask...Filipino's really eat Salads? Well at this restaurant they do, and probably to cater the healthy SF crowd. But it missed the marks for me as there was a lot of residual oil...enough to make a healthy food nut go ballistic. But alas, I should have known being a Filipino myself...we love our oil...it's essential in all our cooked goods and come to find out in their Salad as well.

To make things better I ordered their Halo Halo. A dessert-must for all Filipinos and non-Filipinos alike. If you don't know what Halo x 2 is, it's essentially a Filipino's version of shaved ice with condensed milk, lots of other sweeter ingredients that I can't name and topped with ice cream!

If you come here, skip the salad and go straight to the fried and oil cooked goodness. Or just go straight to the dessert!
author: Andrew S.

description: Its been weeks i have ate my people food ever since i moved. Its a good place if you want to eat some and your a college student. There are other places, it good for me.
author: Ryan H.

description:
I was in the neighborhood earlier today and decided to give this place a shot.  After reading some of the reviews I was quite skeptical of the quality of the food.  I have had my fair share of Filipino food (homemade, stateside, in the PI, chain, mom-and-pop, etc) and think I'm pretty critical when it comes to taste and execution.  

Overall experience at Inay's was great.  Welcomed by the lady behind the counter, letting me know of all the items available, even the items around the corner near the grill that was hard to see.  I went with the beef caldareta (spicy stew) with 1/2 steamed rice 1/2 pansit (noodles).  The flavors were on point and the meat was tender.  The veggies were fresh and flavorful.  Just like some of the prior reviews, the entrees could have been heated up a bit more.  Maybe a periodical stir while in the steam trays may do the trick.  

One entree with rice and noodles with a small soda for ~$10 seemed like a fair price for a quick, easy, and tasty Filipino lunch.  I'll definitely be back again.
author: PJ F.

description:
For $7.99, you get a one entree meal with either seasoned rice or pancit (stir fry noodles) in a somewhat Panda Express fashion.

Service is subpar - quite slow and unorganized. I spent about 10 minutes waiting while one server attended to his grill, an associate serving two very indecisive teeny bops, an untrained register associate, and another associate talking to the server tending to his grill.

In terms of food, flavor is good, and portions are generously filling. I had the pancit (really tasty) and pork adobo (love the pork belly and very tasty).

It's not a 5 star eatery, but it'll fill ones hungry appetite.
author: Alex C.

description:
I'm very glad that there is Filipino restaurant in downtown SF. I went twice to try different kinds of Filipino dishes they have. My first experience was good I had garlic fried rice and pansit with lechon paksiw and it was delicious, the server was friendly and the cashier as well.
The second time I went and brought a friend. I was totally disappointed not with the food but to the server, I asked to have a sample of Bicol express, and notice that the server wasn't wearing a gloves and what scares me is that his finger nails was very dirty( it was disgusting), so, instead of having that sample, I just did not have it. I believe that the proper hygiene wasn't met, and this is a big health issue.
author: Genesis T.

description: I came here before a movie to get a little dinner. The food isn't bad but doesn't have much flavor. I love Filipino food for the flavors, this doesn't have it.
author: Justin S.

description:
This was my 2nd trip. First time I came, I ordered the breakfast: tocino, egg over rice.  I told the lady I needed the egg well done. When I got the order I was told by the cook that they only cook it one way sunny side up.  I told him then you need to tell your salesforce that because I specifically told her I wanted the egg well done. And it took more than 15 minutes to get the incorrect order!  She gave me a free egg roll to apologize for the delay.  Service is slow! (Excuse I said they are still new and it was just the 2nd week after openng.)
Today, I came for arroz caldo and a pork BBQ stick. REALLY SHOCK when I was charged $3.99 for the BBQ.  "RIPP OFF" - OK sana kung masarap but no just so.so. !
I've heard from my other co-workers, too and  they are not liking it either. It's really too bad.  It's overprice!
author: Mary G.

description: I may say highly recommended especially to those who missed the Fil cuisine. What more with a place at everyones convenience.
author: Robbleeav D.

description:
"Ang bagal!!!!"

For a fast food joint in an area with high foot traffic, I'm not sure why they were so gd slow. I could think of multiple excuses, actually. Enough for me to think while waiting in line for 20 minutes. 

Hey guys, ever heard of Panda Express?
author: Dennis D.

description: I think I've eaten enough adobo and lumpia to be considered part philipino. And I'm sorry to say I was a little disappointed in Inay's offering. Although it is nice to see this in such a central location, I thought the food poor. My bbq was mostly fat but tasty, the adobo lacking flavor, and what's up with not having caldareta ? Also way too much plastic being utilized, and utensils are so flimsy they are useless making the eating experience a challenge. Fil-Am still my choice, it's just far away from here .
author: Matt A.

description:
I don't like to give places 2 stars, especially a Filipino Restaurant. But I need to do this so they can make improvements now to save their potentially successful business. My main complaint is they are EXTREMELY SLOW! I agree with the other reviewers here. I came here last Saturday and I was in line for 30 minutes! I understand they are new but there were like 15 people working there, 5 in the front and I kept seeing more and more coming out from the back (seemed like they were getting up from bed or a nap back there).

There was no system whatsoever. The older lady wrote the orders on the container but didn't even fulfill them correctly. Everyone looked like they were sleeping, meanwhile 30 people in line! However, the food is good. But I don't know if it's worth 30 minute wait.
author: Maria V.

description: great filipino food for being in a food court, legit, i grew up in the philippines so I know my food. I always go for the breakfast plate, tocino+longannisa, garlic rice and two eggs. YUM!
author: kristopher v.

description: A bit pricy but you'll get your money's worth. The food is great and you'll enjoy traditional Filipino food
author: Adrian T.

description:
LONGSILOG!! Yes, it is legit here. Too legit to quit. Note, it is referred to here as "1-item breakfast with longanisa". Order it, eat it, enjoy the party in your mouth!

And hey, perfect pre or post movie grub. Come for a flick and stay for some dope Filipino eats.
author: Henry L.

description: This place is bomb. I love eating the pancit, bicol express, and bangus belly, or one of the chicken or pork skewers. They have so many other items that are nice like the lumpia or the other finger foods. I haven't tried everything I just stick with my usual combo and it never gets old. I try to eat here 3-4 times a week because the prices are worth the food.
author: Samiere T.

description: Ordered the two entre meal, and chose Kare-Kare and Ampalaya Guisado. So-so. They were lazy with the garlic fried rice and just tossed garlic chips and green onions (?) in it. The meal was filling but pretty boring. You can't expect much from turo-turo, even if it's right smack in the middle of downtown San Francisco. Best mango juice I've had in a while though.
author: Nat V.

description: Meh - the chicken skewer was so-so and overpriced.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Skews unhealthy.

Your enthusiasm for things that are "fried to golden perfection" will go a long way towards your star rating. There is a lot to choose from.

Closer inspection also reveals $4 grilled chicken skewers marinated with a homemade BBQ sauce. My enthusiasm suddenly perked up.
