Traditional Filipino food and myself just aren't meant to be. Enjoyed my skewer and the friendly staff. Everyone else can enjoy the rest.
author: Jason B.

description:
I stopped by Inay FIlipino Kitchen this past weekend. I was going to Target to pick up a few things and noticed it. Being Filipino I decided that I would try it out. 

I would say the food was average. I ordered the 2 item combo with the Pork BBQ skewer and Pinakbet. The BBQ was good, but the Pinakbet was just OK. I definitely have had better, but it's decent if you are craving Filipino food in the city.

Overall the food is OK, but I think it is a bit pricey. I'm not used to paying $11 for a 2 item combo of Filipino food.
author: Richard P.

description:
Inay is in the new Metreon center.  Lots of restaurants in the upscale food court right outside the theater box office.  Makes it easy to see a movie and get some cheap quick eats.  

Took a look at Inay and had to try the pancit noodles and the Filipino fried chicken.  The chicken was good but the pancit was a bit disappointing.  

Accessible Filipino food for those of us who are unfamiliar with the cuisine.
author: Doctor G.

description: The food is decent, there's huge portions and it's a great safe introduction to Filipino food to those not familiar with the cuisine. I am tickled that there's Filipino food at the Metreon. There really should be more Filipino food in this city. I drool over their palabok. It's really tasty.
author: Caroline N.

description: Tasted their pork skewers with calamansi sauce at the grand re-opening of the Metreon. They were tender and flavorful. Looking forward to tasting more dishes and perhaps even ordering a full pig (Lechon) for a party!
author: Marina N.

description: I love filipino food, but this place is disgusting. I ordered the fried tilapia, bbq sticks, pinakbit, and pork menudo. I'm sorry to say that I was disappointed with it all. I heard OK reviews but this place takes the cake of one of the filipino food place that is so horrid that I had to toss it out.
author: Patricia R.

description: I love filipino food for the savory salty meats and this place doesn't disappoint! I had white rice with a pork skewer (amazing) and pork adobo. For comfort food that's fast and inexpensive, try this place out.
author: M. D.

description: Ang tagal ng serbisyo!  Importanteng mabilis ang paghahansa ng pagkain.  So guys kung nagmamadali kainin ang nasa istante dahil kung lulutuin pa mga 30 minutes bago kayo makakain. Sayang. Great location, not great food pero pwede na pangtawid gutom.
author: Robert E.

description: Poor review mostly due to the service.  Was asked if I was ready to order, said yes, turned my head for about 3 seconds to make sure my wife was also ready, and the employee walked away and spent a minute on her cellphone with her back facing us. Tried to order the kale salad with a chicken skewer but the employee said we had to choose a side. Pretty sure I was forced into buying extra but didn't feel like arguing.  Food was decent but I would definitely try another option in the food court.
author: Nickolas P.

description: We decided to try some filipino food in the metreon mall.  We've tried other places here before and weren't really impressed.  However the filipino kitchen exceeded expectations today.  The lady working there was really friendly.  We had the Sisig Fries and Sinigag Molasses Chicken Wings with garlic rice and punsit.  The portions overall is huge and is reasonable for the prices.  Actually pretty cheap for the amount of food you get.  The fries were excellent, you get more meat than potatoes.  The Thai chili sauce was not spicy and was kind of on the bland side, but it was still good.  There are bell peppers and a mango salsa that really continues to surprise you with flavors.  The chicken wings were really good too.  It's not crisy, but more saucy.  The sauce is vinegary and has a hint of sweetness.  However, the garlic rice was OK, kind of dry.  The punsit was pretty good, typical stir fried noodles.  Overall, I'd recommend trying this place out!
author: Kevin N.

description:
We Filipinos like eating our foods with "Sabaw" on the side but be warned, they'll charge you for the container, am I right Mai?
 
Food - 1 Star
Service - 0 Star - why?  very very very bad service!  Super Slowwww and their attitude S%$*s too.  Click "Useful" below if this is true.

The owner should hire new servers... PRONTO!
I'll miss the Grilled Bangus Belly but I ain't coming back here until they get new people.
author: Joyce M.

description: I have only been here a couple of times but the services was great and the bbq pork and chicken was awesome.  I love some great Filipino food !
author: Phillip J F.

description: Good dishes served quickly.  1-entry combo is actually quite filling.  If you're not familiar with Filipino cuisine, try the adobo and a pancit for one of the side
author: Dan C.

description:
So apparently this place just opened up last Saturday?  

Here's the deal:  this is pretty much the exact same stuff you would get at a Filipino family party - but fortunately it was at the family member's house that could cook ok.  

This means two things.  

One is It's legit enough.  Tastes like you would expect pork adobo, bbq chicken skewers, etc to taste.  Nothing more, nothing less.

The other is the flip side (see what I did there) - you could literally, and might even have in the past - made this same stuff at home.  

Some might say it's pricey (paid $10 for a 2 item plate that was more than filling), but you know what, so is the Thai and Korean stuff on the other end of the room.  

That being said, it's 3.5 stars.  It gets 4 because the girl knew I wanted my adobo served OVER the rice, not on the side.  Good call.
author: Louie M.

description:
It's always funny going to Filipino food joints with my Mama, who is an ultimate Filipino chef (as all children of Filipino mothers will proclaim). My mom has been here a couple of times before and her only judgements were, as Mother said:

1) They don't smile at me
2) They take too long

These being her only criticisms about this place, figured it shouldn't be too bad.

I had Longsilog, and she had Sisig and fried rice, and we had a side of lumpia. 

Great thing about the longanisa was it wasn't oily! If you're familiar with longanisa, you know it sometimes squirts oil when you slice it or stick your fork in it, and it's so off-putting! Not at Inay. It's cooked perfectly. Aside from that, you really can't f*ck up an egg and rice...

...BUT the RICE... oh the garlic rice. It made me sad. It was undercooked and bland, kind of tasted like chalk, which kind of sucks because garlic rice should be a GIVEN with Filipinos. Hence, the deduction of one star.

Sisig-- NAILED it. Inay has got they're sisig right. Keep that up. 

And another star deduction for the wait. I think they can and should figure out a quicker way to prepare their food that not only maintains some of the food quality, but IMPROVES it... Inay, I'm talking about the GARLIC RICE! I want better GARLIC RICE! :)
author: Jennifer A.

description: Just had the garlic rice and pork sinigang. The garlic rice is really good. The sinigang was nice and hot. Hit the spot. Eating filipino food at the mall takes a little getting used to. I'm sure I'll come back and try more of their menu.
author: richard d.

description: I like the chicken barbecue.  The marinade is different from the traditional Filipino barbecue, but still great tasting.  The chicken meat was tender and juicy.  I found the caldereta on the salty side and lacks color from the green peas, carrots and tomato sauce.  That's why I dropped 1 star.  The bistek (Filipino beef steak) is pretty good.  It has a well balanced flavor between the tangy and salty flavors from the lime and soy sauce.  The meat in the caldereta and bistek were very tender.  The lumpia shanghai was tasty, not greasy.  Overall, I will go back and I highly recommend Inay Filipino Kichen.
author: Cynthia F.

description:
Yum yums in my tum tums. I wish this place was a real restaurant instead of inside the Metreon. I think it would do wonders if more ppl knew about it. Everything tasted delicioso...... Power to the flips!!

- Garlic Fried Rice
- Chicken/Pork Adobo 
- Dinuguan
- Pansit
- BBQ Pork Skewer
- Halo-Halo w/ Mango ice cream

#yummmmkins!
author: Monalisa M.

description: I liked the ube binka bite. Yum! I can't wait to try my next binka!
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: I was born and raised in the Philippines. I was hesitant to write a review regarding my experience as I was proud to have a Filipino restaurant in the city, but when I tried the food, it was soggy and unappealing. It also made me have an unsettling and upset feeling in my stomach. I was feeling fine before the meal, but after I tasted the food, I wanted to puke. I wish that there were better restaurants in the Bay Area representing Filipino food. This establishment may work very hard, and I feel sorry for posting a negative review on a Filipino restaurant but perhaps I just did not have a good experience. I would not recommend.
author: Esperanza G.

description: $14 for a one item combo and 8 pcs lumpia shanghai and it doesn't include a drink. A lil steep
author: Nina C.

description:
Walang kwenta! Parang Bebel gam. Langya.

The meat on the adobo was like bubble gum. How can you f that up? I would rather drive to San Bruno to get a decent filipino meal than walk nearby to this establishment. I want Filipino Food to succeed in America but if our restaurants think they can just eat microwaved bullshit, think again.  I spent $20 on a hungry stomach and I was not happy. To the owners, please please try your food during the day when your kids are watching the place. They don't even look like they wanna work there. Filipinos are getting smarter with their food. Drive out to San Bruno and taste any of the food at Tribu or Patio Filipino. Try to make it close to that. Or just sell lumpia and longanissa with garlic rice if you can't keep it fresh. But don't sell me this half ass food. Please make it better so I can walk to lunch and buy decent filipino food close by. There are so many asian restaurants here in SOMA that im sad that this place will fail if it doesnt try to improve the food. Its just sad that Jollibee was better than this. 

I gave it an additional star since the bbq was decent. Other than that. Try to avoid this place if you've never tasted filipino food. Go to the Senor Sisig Truck or drive out to San Bruno and yelp any of those restaurants there to choose one. LA and NY have their Filipino Restaurants sh* together. San Francisco still need to pickup the quality. Cmon SF!
author: jp i.

description:
Monday bbq pork n bistek tagalog was good with pansit n garlic rice...,
But today booo on their sinigang pork Only vegie was radish n pork was all fat n tendons n the steam rice was low quality brand rice...  Lunch was not worth the pay... Service was slow n staff were not friendly..
author: I H.

description: Had the bistek and beef caldereta. It was quite good! The bistek was not as tender as I wanted it to be but it has a very good flavor. The caldereta was superb. I've also tried their arroz caldo, pandesal with ice cream and halo-halo and they were delicious! I'll definitely be back. The portions are huge. One item with rice is $7.99. Two items with rice is $9.79. I think it's priced well for the portions they give you. You will not leave hungry!
author: elaine s.

description: B-L-A-N-D Filipino food served fast food style.  :-(
author: Kit P.

description: They're too expensive for Filipino food that's not authentic. They're trying to Americanize the food too much. I'd rather go to Kusina ni Tess in the Tenderloin :)
author: Kathy P.

description:
inay, i'm a little peeved. while your food was delicious the first few weeks we dined regularly (twice a week!), it has become somewhat inconsistent. for example, your sisig that i so touted with all its merits -- namely that you actually used pig ears that added nice crunch to the dish -- last week, when i ordered my beloved sisig, there was no crunch in sight -- er, mouth! how disappointing!

but even more aggravating is that we came, out of our way, 2 Sundays ago at 7:30 pm really looking forward to our usual filipino dinner and was told the grill was already off and cleaned; most of the buffet line had been cleared, and what was left was cold and had congealed. we asked what time you closed, and you said 8:30 pm. What?! what were you going to do for the last hour? not serve people?
author: Melissa N.

description: This is the equivalent of a good "carinderia" style eatery in the Philippines. With that being said, we didn't expect much because it's not your upscale restaurant type of place. The food was really good and the portions were huge. Good place to grab something quick when you're hungry and want something cheap.
author: Emil A.

description: I had pancit from this place and felt very sick yesterday. later i woke up with a high fever and vomiting non stop at 3am and this keept going this well still now 6am. I needed something to eat and it looked decent though but i should have left! I need to go on a 6-8 hour drive to LA now and i can't even get my fever down. I do not get easily sick like this either. NEVER AGAIN!
author: Jane L.

description: Food was ok normal taste nothing too special... Very very poor services, learn how to count what people order not just press numbers on the screen n over charge...
author: Richard C.

description:
I was conflicted on how to rate this place.
The food is decent, but there was so much room for improvement.

I'd like my comments to be constructive so they can improve.  Because, as many other patrons who like their food, I'm also rooting for them to be successful.

The service - like most Filipino restaurants (such as the Jollibee that used to be in the area), they always seem to be very confused.  The layout of the place looks like there's an assembly line, but people walk all over the place.  The cash register walks to the grill, the cook walks to the cash register.  They seem very disorganized and not efficient.  I hate seeing this in Filipino fast food.  It's like it's one big party in the back, and customers just wait until they get their shit together.
Each person averages about 10-15 mns to get their order.  I almost didn't want to be repeat customer because of this.

My suggestion: sit your staff down and talk about coming up with a process.  Talk about roles, and talk about different scenarios and how to handle them.  You're probably all buddies in the back, but that doesn't mean you can't be professional.  Take a page out of Panda Express.  I'd much rather give my $$ to you guys if I don't have to wait 15 mns every time.

I don't like there's a lot of asking each other questions.  The cash register (in all 3 of my visits) had to go ask someone to ask someone what the full order was).  There's always asking each other for status, or order updates, or price, etc.  VERY CONFUSED BUNCH OF PEOPLE.

Unless you get your act together and be more efficient, you'll lose people just because of your line.

Utensils - We're eating meat.  Owners and staff, please try eating one of your bangus with your own plastic utensils.  The only good thing is that their compostable.  But my fork and knife bent all over the place.
I HATE this about Filipino restaurants too.  They don't think of the usability of their materials where their customer will eat.  This place is pricey enough that inconveniences like that are really less tolerated (especially by potentially returning patrons).

Make sure your spoon can reach the bottom of your cups for halo halo.

It's simple things like this that sets your service apart.  You have a TON of competition in the food industry.  You have people who are trying Filipino food for the first time.  Give them a good experience.  Not just good (or at least decent) food.
author: ny n.

description:
I have been at Inay's on three occasions and all of them, I was dragged by a friend or family. Twice, I was not impressed with the food so the last time I went, I decided to try the Filipino breakfast. I figured, they couldn't go wrong with cooking marinated tocino and frying bangus belly. I waited for 15 minutes to get my food. The other server was trying to tell me that it's coming but I had been standing there for a while and I got really impatient. I tried to ask the person managing the cash register. Her name is CINDY. You can't miss her: She is a short Filipino woman (obese with midget-like features), unhappy, and looked very miserable. She said, "You ordered a short-order dish so it will take a long time to cook." She said that in a loud tone and very angry face. Mind you that I saw the server as he was getting the tocino and fish (already cooked) and they were only going to warm it up.  I couldn't help myself but remind her that the least she could say was that she's sorry. She had the nerve and the audacity to reason out. I got so upset that I asked them to  refund my money. An older and pleasant lady, who apparently is the owner, came out to say sorry and spoke to me. She was apologetic and asked me to forgive the delay. She even came out to speak to me after to let me know how sorry she was. She definitely knew the meaning of customer service and knew how to treat customers. The question is  how can she have an employee like Cindy?

Cindy has ZERO customer service and as I was standing there, I felt so ashamed of myself witnessing this very sad person treat my other 'kababayans' with the same nasty, unprofessional, and VERY RUDE attitude. She was less rude to other non-Filipino customers. 

I am Filipino myself and I do support every Filipino establishment and organization. However, the owner of Inay's should do something to this unhappy woman. She is ruining the business with her attitude, demeanor, and poor customer service. She should be placed in the kitchen where no one can see her. She is such a disgrace to this Filipino establishment and I feel ashamed that she is Filipino.  Watch out for this woman cashier - Cindy is her name!
author: Edwin C.

description:
i almost feel bad for writing this review, but jesus christ the food here is terrible!

i want filipino food to be successful & enjoyed by all in america, but this place ain't cutting it. it's almost embarrassing how amateur the food is. i understand it's technically fast food, but if you're going to spend about $30 for "fast food", you might as well drive to san bruno and have some decent filipino food.

i was here on thursday, just when it opened. they were barely prepared. only few pieces of food were lined up, waiting for chumps like myself. don't get me wrong, i totally understand that they have to take time and prepare... but like, if you're going to take your sweet ass time getting the food ready, shouldn't it taste good?

their pansit palabok is drenched in sauce. ok i know it's pansit palabok, but there was something funky about it. it was just super wet and had a funny taste, plus the noodles were kind of chewy. 

their beef tapa is hard to chew, it's also hard to cut. i admit that it was flavorful, but you would only be able to find that out if you had razors for teeth or something.

i was going to try the bangus belly, but they didn't prepare it yet and apparently didn't know when it would be out to serve.

honestly! i probably wouldn't have minded this place as much, if their SERVICE WASN'T HORRIBLE. which it was btw. the cashier had such an attitude! she made exaggerated facial expressions whenever you would order something. i know working in food service is hard, but suck it up. you don't need to have an attitude if someone is trying to BUY something. how do you expect your business to make money?

my expectations aren't high. i know this is supposed to be quick and simple food. i don't expect five star food and service, but i just want to be able to enjoy lunch with my mom after going to target or something.

i wanted to like this place, but just... no. unless some things change, i don't see myself coming back. 

the only thing they didn't mess up was the halo halo, but i don't know how you could even try to mess that up.
author: Tiffany B.

description: Good Filipino take-out at decent prices. They have a good variety from garlic rice to pancit (be sure to ask for lemon to sprinkle on it!) to dinuguan (if you dare). One item ~$8, two items ~$10. Not the best thing ever, but nice to have some variety if you are shopping at Target or headed into a movie @ the Metreon.
author: Karen C.

description: You can't fail on rice. Seriously. The rice was brittle and hard. Let down :-(
author: Desirea O.

description: The food sits there in the open all day, so it's hardly ever freshly cooked. The employees just stand around leaning over the counters and play with their phones even when there are customers. Definitely over-priced for how mediocre the food is. The only star goes to the calamansi juice. Eat somewhere else.
author: Jeffrey V.

description: What can I say... I expected more..like always disaapointed with the outcome. Their employee dont smile and ignores you and very rude. Never coming back! thank you very much!
author: Mickey M.

description: Unless you love Filipino food don't eat here! My hot date (aka my husband) and I went to Metreon to see a movie. We stopped to have a bite to eat. I went to the steak place which is always good and priced well. My husband went to Inay. He'd never had Filipino food before and I don't think he wants it ever again. He hasn't stopped talking about how disgusting this food was. He couldn't even eat the rice! It was so greasy and actually smelled bad. He's Puerto Rican and has never come across plain old white rice he wouldn't eat. The grilled chicken skewer turned out to be chicken hearts. The pork in adobo was ALL fat and grizzle Everything was beyond gross. On top of it all it cost $16 for a plate of food and a drink. If I could rate zero stars I would just to keep people from eating here.
author: Maria G.

description: Over priced Filipino fast food that's for sure. 2 items with a drink almost $20?! Taste is not even that great. Kare kare is bland & why the heck is the bagoong freaking sour?!!  Might as well go a block west on Mission & eat at JT Restaurant.
author: Jays D.

description: I have been to Filipino food restaurants and also good old' jolly bee but this food kitchen is nothing like traditional let alone American fusion filipino food. The sine gang is watered down salt and the pancit is comparative to schloppy wet noodles that are obviously cooked way too long as well as being thrown in from the day before. 2 stars for MY effort in trying the place out. I do have an expensive food palate and wish I could better stomach the food court but alas, this is proof that you get what you pay for.
author: Sarah T.

description: I ordered the beef caldereta, pork adobo, and pancit.  The food was very good, meat was tender and flavorful.
author: AJ M.

description: Nice to see this place at the Metreon. I was craving some filipino food so it was perfect that we were here and everything looked good. I ordered the beef steak with garlic rice. While the portions are hefty, it lacked a little in flavor. The garlic rice was good but the beef steak needed more flavor, more pizzaz. The BF ordered Kare-Kare. He was a little disappointed with his as well....what lacked was the flavor. It may have just been an off day for them...but I would definitely go back and try other dishes....better luck next time :)
author: Mel P.

description: Sorry for the downgrade, but the last time I ate there their food was cold.  Malfunctioning hot table? I don't know, but they needed to microwave my plate if they know they were serving COLD food.  So, sad.  GET it together, Inay!
author: Jonsey B.

description: Not impressive! Ate there several times since I work nearby, always not satisfied. Halo halo needs more ingredients-mostly ice. Take away the ice cream and the whole thing is a waste. Why cant they add banana, sweet potato or even sago and gulaman- they are all cheap. Ordered lechon kawali one time, the skin is so soft and not crunchy- wasted my money. Bbq is too salty and does not have the inviting aroma. Boneless bangus is too dry. One time my coworker ate the Bicol express- did not see for days due to lbm. Lastly, they should serve anything with sauce or juice in a bowl container not squeezing it with the rest of your plate. Not a fan here.
author: Art M.

description: Food is delicious; reminds me of home cooking. Their selections, reminds me of family potluck parties. However their service lacks organization; most especially the young lady at the register. Maybe she can take orders or restock instead; because multitasking is not for her. I also feel they should have a sign indicating where the line begins. I'd give 4 stars BUT having to wait over 15 minutes with only 1-person ahead of us for an order of halo halo. That's too long of a wait.
author: Phillip B.

description: 3 1/2 stars. The food is okay, but nothing close to the food you'd have at a Filipino family/house party. The ladies working there are super sweet, and I'd probably go back just because of the kind service.
author: Eduardo R.

description: Nice selection of traditional Filipino food, including dinuguan (pork blood stew) and bistek (sauteed beef with onions).  A bit pricey, but one portion is certainly enough to share between two.
author: Kris B.

description: Been here a couple times and thought it was good.  The halo halo was great.  My fish was overcooked, though (gotta be careful with overcooking thin pieces of meat, guys...c'mon).  Beef stew was good.  Overall, it tastes like many of the homemade filipino foods you may have had at birthday parties and the like.  Service is ok.  Much better than Jollibee.  The guy who tried to compare Jollibee to this place, you gotta bee joking.
author: Ken B.

description: We wanted a cheap but delicious food and that's what we got. We ordered Bicol Express and Adobo and both were great! They give huge servings as well so we shared the two entree combo plus extra rice. That's $12+ for 2 people.
author: Ira A.

description: Cool joint to grub on some Philipino food. $10 for a plate with either garlic rice or Pancit with a choice if 2 sides.
author: T L.

description: For "mall food", it sure is tasty. Good selection of food also. Reminds me of being in the Philippines actually. The lady behind the counter was super nice. We ordered the 2 dish platter and garlic rice of course. 2 huge balls of garlic rice! Nobody knows rice like Filipinos! Other Asians skimp on rice, that just ain't right. So anyway, I ordered the beef steak and dinuguan, my partner ordered pork adobo and caldereta. They give pretty good size servings. Price is $9.99 for each platter which is not bad. If you want just one dish it's $7.99. Everything tasted exactly the way they're supposed to, which is a good thing. Almost reminded me of my mom's cooking.. almost, since no one on Earth can ever beat my mom's cooking haha. Hey I'll be coming here often.. esp since it's in the Metreon close to soon to open CityTarget and of course AMC. Oh and we showed up at 11am so I didn't notice slow service, we were served right away and food was ready.
author: Vol T.

description: Located in the newly designed Metreon, it sits lonely in one corner of the food court.  The selection is pretty vast and they have an all-day breakfast menu.  Filipino food places aren't too common in the sea of Vietnamese, Thai  and Japanese restaurants in the city, or in general.  It's good to try something different once a while.  Tried the Beef Steak Togalog.  Meat was tender, mixed with some onions and juicy.  Great served over the garlic rice or one could request 1/2 fried and 1/2 garlic rice combo.  For the portions, the price was just right.  Who said you couldn't have a hearty meal in the heart of SF under $10?
author: A t.

description: Had their lumpia seriwa and was disappointed on the taste, but their bbq sticks on the other hand where tasty and flavorful and priced accordingly.
author: Katherine V.

description: I grew up in Daly City smelling my neighbor's heavenly barbeque vingear chicken in the back yard. I've had wonderful home cooked Filipino food and Inay is not bad. Pricing is questionable: I paid $7.98 for two 12 inch chicken skewers with NO side included. The mango slushie is perfect- Great mango flavor and not overly sweet will worth the $4.49 price I paid.
author: Pinky F.

description: This is one of the best authentic Filipino food I've had in a while that is logistically easy to get to in SF.  Great portion for a reasonable price!  I ask for the 1/2 noodle + 1/2 garlic fried rice combo with another dish otherwise they will give you three scoops of garlic fried rice.  Some dishes are acquired taste like the diniguan (pork blood stew) but don't be afraid to try other dishes which are delicious.  I order something different each time I go so I know which ones to recommend to my friends.  I come here once a week now.  ;-)
author: Renee S.

description: Enjoyed their pork and chicken skewers, lumpia and noodles! Very delicious! Looking forward to their Grand Opening at the Metreon!  I heard it is around the 18th of July!  Skewers would be amazing for a party!
author: Shawnna W.

description:
Tasted their grilled bangus belly, Yum!!  Done really well.
Halo-halo with ube was done with the right sweetness and texture of ingredients was as I expected - it was a great blend!
author: Belle De Villa L.

description: I've been here once, and I don't think I'm going back.  The worker took my order and basically got it confused with another order and gave my food to someone else.  It baffles me how the workers didn't think anything was wrong when I was just standing there by the cash register for the longest time, but it seemed that they just didn't care.  I waited for about 15 min and had to ask them before they realized what happened.  Then it was another 10 min of prepping the food.  The manager was really nice and gave me some samples to munch on while I waited, but the food was just okay.
author: Joy Z.

description: I was excited to see a Filipino restaurant located outside in downtown.  Unfortunately, they still have to make a lot of improvements.  First, the people are VERY SLOOOW, and they also seem sooo bored and unhappy with what they are doing.  Second, the food list is great but the tastes are very bland.  If you are going to open an "ethnic" restaurant, why do you have to change the recipes so they taste so bland?  Even the turon had no taste and no sugar!  I hope that the owners make this a more authentic Filipino food place and hire people who know how to  deal with the customers.
author: Ben F.

description: I read all the bad reviews and still decided to try the place. I called beforehand to figure out where in the Metreon this place and the person on the phone was absolutely rude. I ordered the all day breakfast with longanisa. The longanisa was the worst I have ever had. The garlic rice didn't taste like such at all. There was more scallions than garlic. The side of onions and tomatoes are tasteless and the eggs didn't taste well either. Overall horrible experience. They need to get it together.
author: Dinorah R.

description: Their food is decent but expensive for a food court. I could still deal with that but their service is just POOR. Those two young ladies serving just treated us like we were in a cafeteria handing out our food just like that. When it was my turn, I was horrified to see this girl about to place the meat with liquidy sauce on the porous brown plate where they serve your rice. I equested that they put it in a container. Girl gave me an annoyed look, the other girl nodded & told her "ako na bahala" meaning she'll deal with it. Deal with it she did! She charged me $0.25 for the container. I don't mind being charged, but be up front about the fact that there is a charge for the container. Don't just include it in my bill & expect me to be okay with it. Inform your costumer about the additional fee, instead of being sneaky about it. Be happy for the 1star. I am giving that for the okay food you serve. You don't really deserve even half a star
author: Rems S.

description: I live a couple blocks away from Metreon so I came here a lot.  I have been eating at Inay's everyday for two weeks.  They really have good food.  I tried a lot of dishes with garlic rice and all of them  were very tasty.  It's true that the serving crew were slow and disorganized.  So, normally, I either came here at around 11:30 am or after 1:30 pm to avoid the crowd.  Once, I came and talked to one of the girls behind the steam table.  Then she went back to the kitchen behind the wall.  10 minutes later, she brought probably a spring roll to another customer.  There was a cashier standing there but she didn't even bother to ask my need.  There were a couple of people behind me waiting in line and they left.  Finally, 15 min later, I got my plate from the steam table.  I wanted to take a lunch break and I didn't mind waiting.
author: Raymond C.

description: Great service!!!  Highly recommended!!!  I was visiting from Arizona and decided to try Filipino Food again.  Quality and service much better than Goldilocks.  Thank You!!!  Will come back again.
author: Beth S.
